This is a complete remake of the decade-old legendary Chinese kung fu RPG.

Despite the English translated version doesn't carry the full spirit of the game in original language, this game would definitely provide western player a great opportunity experiencing the Chinese Wuxia culture.

Unlike some disappointing AAA games where the ending involves with space magic and different cut scene color, your decision in this game does matter and will heavily affect the story line and ending.  Almost all event decisions affect the ending in some way.  The story branch out into about four different main storyline in late game.

It is rare to see RPG nowadays where I really took my time to consider what I should answer, or decide what I should do when there is an NPC event --- which side should I help?" "how about just take this item by force?" "it would be the best if I do nothing and stay out of this?".  Decisions do MATTER in this game.

Replay value is high.  I finished my first playthrough at around 35 hours.  So just three playthough will yield more than 100 hours

Where to start? Well, the game is amazing. I'm only a little way into it but I can tell it is going to be ridiculously massive. Every skill seems to unlock something else - new characters turn up or I get a new ability or martial art or can make better stuff or whatever. Okay, yeah, that's how most games with a skill system work, but given that my character ended up drinking cheap wine till he gained the power of Drunken Kung Fu from a magical hobo I think it's safe to say that the skills you get are really unexpected and seriously fun. I wouldn't be surprised if you managed to master flower arranging and ended up being able to decapitate a man by pelting him with a handful of rose petals. The sheer amount of stuff available might be a bit intimidating to some people, but a good tip is just to grind hunting because then at the end of the day you can (I never thought I'd ever type this) go home and eat a big bag of tiger ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for massive stat boosts.

The graphics are pretty nice - the 'control your guy and run around doing Kung Fu' sections aren't super ultra realistic high-def but it's still all nicely detailed and looks good. That and the music combines perfectly to really set up the atmosphere.

The combat sections aren't too bad either. It all plays out fairly well, there are (as far as I've seen anyway) no giant drawn out combats or sections where you can tell the dev's were making something else and didn't have time to really perfect this combat or that fight. I will say that early on some people might think otherwise (There are some brutally hard fights) but early on in the game don't forget you are playing an ordinary guy just starting out in the Kung Fu superhero business.

Now, onto the flaws. There have been a few people complaining about a bug where not being in fullscreen makes the keyboard stop responding, but I've never seen that or had the game crash so I can't comment. The translation is the only thing close to a complaint I have, and given how the game was actually translated I suppose I can't be too harsh. The developers basically open sourced it and got the fans of the series to help them out, so yeah, there are going to be sections where it is perfectly translated into The Queen's English and sections where urteh baonfo legging, though thankfully there's more of the former than the latter. Thanks to the size difference between English and Chinese text though, there are quite a few sections where the text overflows from a page and you can't read it all and where font sizes change from section to section so everything can fit in. If they keep working on the translation then yeah, this'll go from being really good to genuinely epic.

Do I recommend this game? Oh hell yes I do. Was I kidding about the Tiger ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? no. That is an actual thing.

The turn-based tactical fighting system is also very intriguing; you had to constantly move your character the find the optimal angle of attack and strategy. The sound design is over the top Asian dude yelling and metal clanking sound is ridiculous great.

I had play the original game back in 05, I would say this remake is a step up in every direction. However the currently states of this game is reported very buggy for many people. reviewText:
Tales of Wuxia is an interesting and unique game that has been translated from China. It's an update of a previous game and the first I'm aware of to make it into English.

What is it? One part is top down RPG, running around, talking to people, doing quests, buying stuff, whatever. Combat is handled in unique turn based RPG style where the accumulated effort of the sim portion determines your characters internal style, martial arts styles and stats.

The sim segments involve you making meaningful and vital decisions in growing your character, do you explore the town and encounter new and strange allies/enemies and possibly even learn new martial arts? Or do you try to master Music, which will learn you powerful techniques in combat?

There's a ton of different skills and minigames involved in raising your tea sipping alchohol drinking kungfu master, many of them interesting, a few sure to be a little frustrating.

Most interestingly, the game is actually pretty in depth with teaching the player a lot of fascinating stuff.

The bad is clear, the game has some technical hiccups which, if you're not comfortable browsing the forum to solve, can prevent you from playing. In my experience, once I figured out how to get the keyboard to work in game I encounter no technical issues as of my near thirty hours in game.

The second is the translation, it begins pretty strong and carries through on the main story comprehnesibly but some paths of various events are translated bizarrely and inconsistantly. If you can appreciate a bad dub, this is more charming than problematic but some segments are simply not translated at all. I'd put the translation at about 99.9% complete, but that .1% does pop up and will irritate some less forgiving.

Ultimately, I love this game. It's full of content, I'm not even done my first playthrough but already I'm looking forward to playing through as a villain, a womanizer, and so on. My first character has dozens of martial arts I haven't even begun to use, not to mention internal styles and so on.

This game really makes you feel like you're raising a badass martial-artist, and presents a full and fascinating Wuxia fantasy world for you to get lost in. I recommend it to anyone who loves unique games, sim-raising games, strategy RPG's, and cool translation gems.

The Good
Unique and well done melding of RPG elements, turn based strategic combat, and sim-raising gameplay
A fascinating world filled with interesting characters to interact with
A ton of replayability!
Meaningful and in-depth choices to grow your character
The best tea sipping alchohol drinking kung fu raising sim ever (small market but still!)
There's a kung fu style you get from learning how to play chess, from music, from even calligraphy!

The Bad
Only 99.9% translated so far it seems.
Some odd jank with keyboard stuff that you'll need to fiddle with initially.
Preset character

reviewText:
I had a lot of trouble with the game in the beginning, because it would always crash within 10 or so minutes of me booting up the game. However, once I got past the beginning and a bit into the game it became a lot more stable, and I have yet to experience a crash like I was having in the beginning.

Tale of Wuxia is a great RPG featuring deep strategical combat, a compelling story, and a great albeit at times very repetitive soundtrack.

The combat has a turn-based, hex-grid strategy system. Based on your various stats you may move a certain amount of hexes. If you strike from in-front of your enemy, they have a much higher chance of countering you. As such your character positioning is very important. Some characters have special effects, such as one of the characters you start with, whose ability is to defend characters he is within one hex of when they get attacked. The combat can get a bit complicated--even though I am only playing on the easiest difficulty, I am having quite some trouble with some of the battles.

Another part of the game you're going to be seeing a lot is perhaps the part of the game I like the least. After the first part of the game, you join a martial arts sect and spend a lot of your time training there. Over time you get access to various activities you may participate in. These include doing chores, training your basics, your internals, your skills, producing wares, and going for a stroll. All of these require stamina, and the only way to recover stamina, is to rest, which after a certain amount of times will progress the story.

A couple of hours into the game, I feel incredibly underpowered, with my main character only surviving one or two blows by an enemy, whereas my supporting characters are a lot more powerful. I know I am supposed to be weaker than them, however I can't help but feel like I did something wrong in training my character.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ A game that does not hold your hand and tells you where to go.  It expects you to explore and fail
+ I'm just at the surface of all the features of the game (after 20 hours)
+ For wuxia lovers, a definite try (especially since it's in English)
+ Many amusing/annoying minigames to simulate mining, smithing, herb gathering etc (the treasure chest puzzle with 4 colours and 20 moves?  insane)
+ The only game so far I know where every NPC has a name or a unique title, and between them they never say the same things.  Sometimes, talking to an NPC will trigger a quest or even a small minigame (usually a riddle)
+ The translation is quite acceptable (if you are a reader of wuxia light novels translated to english, it feels similar).  Humourous at times, poetic at others.

Cons:
+ I hate the music, or it's just me.  If they took the soundtrack from Prince of Qin it would be so much better.  (FHXY : PLEASE TAKE NOTE!!!!!)
+ You really need to know a lot about wuxia (internal arts, battle style, meridian systems, chinese poetry etc) to make heads or tails of it.  I can guess it will be very difficult for people who has little knowledge or appreciation of wuxia.
+ Potential to really screw up your character build if you have no idea what you are doing.  Too many stats (though it will be explained to you slowly over the course of 10 to 20 hours of gameplay)
+ Translation bugs (a few npc did not have complete translation.  So unless you can read chinese, either get someone who can to help you, or just spray and pray).  As mentioned by some other reviewers, some description for people/items are not complete as it got cut off. (if some items can have its font minimized to fit into the description box, why not others.  Don't be lazy, developers)

Advice for players
+ Google is your friend (barely)
+ The meridian system translation will be found in your character sheet - books - medicine.  Then take a picture of each meridian point (cheat...lol).  you will ace every medicine task (crucial to access pellet making ie potion making.  Pellets and potions are very expensive at game start, and few and far.  Some pellets/potions provide permanent boosts to your attribute, so swig em.)
+ Many of the poetry and sayings mentioned are directly translated from Mandarin (that's why it sounds so exotic/ridiculous depending on your POV)....pay attention when they are bolded or different colour (usually an indication a minigame or riddle will come up)
+ you will start really really weak, compared to other games where you start able to hack and kill normal mobs.  IF you cannot win, try to keep your (personal) character from dying.  Use the experts that the game usually include for you to weaken or kill the enemies.  In due course, you will grow.  The game letting you use other experts with other weapons and internal styles is to give you a picture of what your character can potentially learn and become (yes, there is a son goku style kamehameha move somewhere in there)
+ don't bother to master all the production /crafting skills - personally i went with mining/smithing/medicine/music.  You won't have time to max them at the start (im not sure about end game...barely there)
+ the more internal skills you obtain and upgrade (even if you don't equip them) the higher your hp and energy will go
+ a lot of the food/tea/wine/consumable stuff provides permanent boosts to hp and energy.  if you have the cash, buy em and eat.  No point to store em.
+ Sometimes the game will proceed when you haven't finish a particular quest.  Deal with it, it's mostly gone.
+ I had 2 crashes.  Once when fiddling with the graphics setting, another when during gameplay.  I cannot comment on the persistent crashes other people are facing, and have no idea.  Try to play on lowest graphical setting
+ talk to everyone and everything.  You never know.  Explore each and every map.  It's not that big.  Buildings can be entered, you will notice a faint golden glow at the entrance, or the doors will open up.
+ safe the game before opening any treasure chest (until you can recognize which one does not require a puzzle to be solved, and which one does) treasure chest keys are not easily obtainable
+ some minigames (for crafting/production)  will frustrate you to the max.  Take it easy.

With the lack of quality wuxia genre games in Steam and most importantly in English, this game however is quite a rough gem.  Certain facets of it is brilliant, while other parts are rough and coarse.  It is hoped the developers or publishers of this game take this into account and do something to polish up the rough and coarse parts.  There has never been a quality wuxia genre game in English (AFAIK, prince of qin nearly 15 years ago pretty good, but not great), and wuxia mmo has been ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ since day one.  Hopefully with Tale of Wuxia (and official patches and upgrades) a new genre will enter the gaming sphere.

-Massive contents involving Chinese history, novelty, literature, art, and culture.
-War Chess style battle interface allowing strategic positioning of your characters.
-Several various ancient Chinese martial art techniques to learn & play with, coupled with attractive effects.
-Single-player Wuxia style games with great story-telling is a dying breed. This one is a classic to behold & embrace.
-Multiple story lines and endings giving it more replayability.

Cons:
-Frustrating random glitches.
-Cut scenes can't be skipped.
-Can't save during battles.
-Some Terrains & objects getting your character stuck while exploring towns & big map.
-Random freezes during various battles, some end battles can't be un-frozen by switching between desktop and the game.
-No rewards given for playing higher difficulties and completing the game.
-Gauntlets for Fist fighting styles are bugged and have zero effects on the stats.
-Weapons have very minimal impacts on your damage/defence.
-Forging the strongest weapons are extremely difficult but since they don't make much difference it's un-rewarding.
-Some of the most powerful techniques are actually weak in this game, making it unsatisfactory to train.
-The battle UI limits to one style, with the more powerful styles of each technique on long CD, greatly reduced the freedom during battles. Even though you can hot-swap techniques this makes it pointless to do so due to the long CD.
-All final battles are very unbalanced. Boss-class enemies deal massive damage.
-Unbalanced enemy buffs especially evasion + combo can go on forever until you die.
-Each story line and ending requires a certain events to be triggered and those events are way too random. In most cases you will be stuck with the exact same story line on every replay unless you get lucky or spend hours save/load all day. And there are no hints to direct you.

Conclusion:
All in all, still a fun game. If you like single-player games with strong stories that involve the Chinese Wuxia background, you will love this game. This is a dying breed that's being destroyed by the online gaming trend. The fact that Herou and the devs are still willing to create a game like this is really appreciative and players should still support them nevertheless. Their efforts should be respected and appreciated. Despite the bugs/glitches, I still give it 8/10. It's a great game in its own right.
